reasoning: The critique targets a subsidiary pessimistic move in §3.2 (that superficially-similar moral views may have low gains from compromise). If that were overturned, it would modestly increase optimism about moral trade, but it wouldn’t undermine the essay’s main conclusions, which hinge more on (i) whether the correct view is linear/unbounded, (ii) power distribution, (iii) feasibility of institutions for trade, and especially (iv) threats and lock-in/blockers. The critique’s core point—that there may be large shared gains from coordinating on avoiding “anti-utopia”/catastrophic bads—has some plausibility, but it only weakly engages the specific “narcissism” claim (about incompatibility when disagreements are over the same domain), and it partly misfires because the essay is largely conditional on survival and already emphasizes the pivotal role of preventing value-destroying threats. It also assumes broad agreement on the badness of suffering/resource-destruction that may not hold across all agents/axiologies. Clear and focused, with little fluff, but not a major problem for the position.
title: Shared agreement on avoiding catastrophic outcomes creates substantial gains from trade
